IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: The mission of the College of Saint Benedict is to provide for women the best residential liberal arts education in the Catholic university tradition. The college fosters integrated learning, exceptional leadership for change and wisdom for a lifetime.
IRS990.MissionDescription: The mission of the College of Saint Benedict is to provide for women the best residential liberal arts education in the Catholic university tradition. The College fosters integrated learning, exceptional leadership for change and wisdom for a lifetime.
IRS990.Description: Higher Education: Educational instruction, 2,045 Fall FTE students enrolled in undergraduate courses, 504 graduates. The College of Saint Benedict designs programs to meet the needs and aspirations of young women, emphasizing women's leadership and a personal development profile that includes intellectual, spiritual, emotional and physical development. Its values-based and value-added residential liberal arts education provides the framework for fulfilling lives of disciplined inquiry and leadership in careers devoted to the professions, public life and service to others.

Activity2.Description: Higher Education: Auxiliary Revenue (dining, housing, etc.) 2,045 students. The Residential Life program at the College of Saint Benedict provides a four year residential experience of community living which supports and challenges our students with opportunities for personal and social growth. This experience allows women to develop an understanding and appreciation of their responsibilities to themselves and others living in the community on campus and beyond. As the residence hall students' primary dining location, the CSB Gorecki is the "kitchen" of the CSB campus community. As in most American homes today, the kitchen is the heart of a home where family congregate and discuss important issues of the day. We encourage our students to dine, relax, and gather with friends at the CSB Gorecki Center thus promoting a feeling of campus community. Dining at the CSB Gorecki Center provides students with the best value for their food dollars.

Activity3.Description: Other program services (Fine Arts Programming, etc.). These areas curate a series of arts events that bring the finest regional and national artists to our community; support and enhance the academic mission of CSB through programming, resources, and personnel; create institutional visibility and recognition through active leadership in local, state, and national arts organizations; provide responsible fiscal management of resources and generate revenue through grants, sponsorships, and ticket sales; create learning initiatives to encourage participation in the arts by "students" of all ages; strengthen community resources in the arts through professional support of regional arts organizations that produce and present in our Fine Arts facilities and provide professional development opportunities for educators to promote interdisciplinary teaching through the arts. Expenses related to these revenues are included in Part IX, Statement of Functional Expenses.

Form990ScheduleCPartIV.Explanation: This amount represents membership dues to Minnesota Private College Council paid in fiscal year '13 and estimated for lobbying purposes. This represents 0.13% of the College's annual operating expenses relating to the exempt status.

OtherSecurities.Description: Beneficial interest in funds held by others

Form990ScheduleDPartXIII.Explanation: Endowment draw is used to fund student scholarships and academic programs

The College follows the accounting standards for contingencies in evaluating uncertain tax positions. This guidance prescribes recognition threshold principles for the financial statement recognition of tax positions taken or expected to be taken on a tax return that are not certain to be realized. No liability has been recognized by the College for uncertain tax positions as of June 30, 2013 and 2012. The College's tax returns are subject to review and examination by federal and state authorities. The tax returns for the current year as well as fiscal years 2010 through 2012 are open to examination by federal and state authorities
Adjustment of actuarial liability on annuities in the amount of -$147,986 and student financial aid in the amount of $35,177,038
Student financial aid in the amount of $35,177,038

Form990ScheduleEPartII.Explanation: College of Saint Benedict includes racially nondiscriminatory policies in newspaper publications for job searches and publications that go out to current and potential students
College of Saint Benedict receives financial aid for students

Form990ScheduleFPartV.Explanation: The Activities By Region section includes the detail for all expenditures made by College of Saint Benedict in foreign countries. College of Saint Benedict shares expenses with another University for these programs. Therefore, the amount of cash sent by College of Saint Benedict to the foreign countries is equal to $4,654,190, of which 48% was charged to St John's University and is reflected on their Schedule F.

Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Explanation: Documentation is maintained and reporting is completed to substantiate grant award uses.

Form990ScheduleJPartIII.Explanation: As a requirement of their contracts, housing is provided for the President, VP Enrollment, and VP Institutional Advancement. Also, fitness club membership is provided for the President.

Form990ScheduleKPartI.DescriptionOfPurpose: Finance construction of new dining building
Refinance 2 prior bonds and fund add'l project
Refinance 5W bonds, originally for various student housing remodeling projects

SecuritiesPubliclyTraded.MethodOfDeterminingRevenues: Avg high and low for day

Form990ScheduleMPartII.Explanation: The number in column (b) represents the total number of contributions of this type. It does not represent the number of stock shares received.
Stock brokers process the stock transactions when the gift is received and the College chooses to liquidate the stock.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, Line 7a
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: As stated in the Articles of Incorporation, the Corporate Members retain the following reserved powers:1) appoint those persons who serve as voting members of the board of Trustees.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, Line 7b
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: As stated in the Articles of Incorporation, the Corporate Members retain the following reserved powers: 1) appoint those persons who serve as voting members of the board of Trustees; 2) approve any merger, acquisition, or dissolution of the Corporation; 3) approve the sale or encumbrance of all or substantially all of the assets of the Corporation; 4) amend the Articles of Incorporation, or 5) make and amend the Bylaws of the Corporation. The Corporate Members are the Sisters of the Order of St. Benedict.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 11b
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The subcommittee of the board of Trustees known as the Audit Committee reviews the 990 during the spring meeting prior to filing of the form and the form is made available for review by all board members prior to filing.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: the Audit Committee reviews all disclosures on the Conflict of Interest policy annually.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: In accordance with the employee handbook, the compensation plan is designed to ensure positions are competitively valued relative to comparable jobs in the market. The Human Resources department does a comparison of job descriptions to position descriptions in the marketplace annually. The comparison for administrative and support staff positions are approved by the President or Board of Trustees and a salary range is created based on this comparison. The President's salary is reviewed and determined by the Board of Trustees. The positions are compared to similar institutions of higher education with respect to enrollment, budget, and Carnegie class found in the College and University Personnel Association salary survey.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, Line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Governing documents and conflict of interest policy are not available to the public, but would be made available upon request. The financial statements are available on the website.
Adjustment of actuarial liability on annuities in the amount of $147,986.
